annotations.shortDefinition: A set of resources composed into a single coherent clinical statement with clinical attestation
annotations.definition: A set of healthcare-related information that is assembled together into a single logical document that provides a single coherent statement of meaning, establishes its own context and that has clinical attestation with regard to who is making the statement.
annotations.comment: While the focus of this specification is on patient-specific clinical statements, this resource can also apply to other healthcare-related statements such as study protocol designs, healthcare invoices and other activities that are not necessarily patient-specific or clinical.
annotations.requirements: To support documents, and also to capture than EN13606 notion of an attested commit to the patient EHR, and to allow a set of disparate resources at the information/engineering level to be gathered into a clinical statement.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

annotation.definition: A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section.
annotation.requirements: Provides computable standardized labels to topics within the document.

annotation.definition: Identifies the primary subject of the section.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications SHALL be aware if the subject changes for a particular section.
annotation.requirements: Subjects can vary within one composition or document, for example mother/baby, patient & relatives, etc.
annotation.rimMapping: unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="PAT"]) or unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="IDENT"]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "ORG") and isNormalEntity()])

annotation.shortDefinition: The actual data for the section
annotation.definition: Identifies the discrete data that provides the content for the section.
annotation.comment: Because composition represent point-in-time snapshots, resource references should either be to a specific version, or made against resources on the same server with full version tracking, so that the correct versions can easily be assembled.
annotation.requirements: Conveys the discrete data associated with the composition.

annotation.definition: A nested sub-section within this section.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: The main event/act/item, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code(s) that apply to the event being documented
annotation.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
annotation.comment: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the typeCode, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more eventCodes are included, they SHALL NOT conflict with the values inherent in the classCode, practiceSettingCode or typeCode, as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation. This short list of codes is provided to be used as “key words” for certain types of queries.

annotation.shortDefinition: The period covered by the documentation
annotation.definition: The period of time covered by the documentation. There is no assertion that the documentation is a complete representation for this period, only that it documents events during this time.

annotation.shortDefinition: Full details for the event(s) the composition concents
annotation.definition: Full details for the event(s) the composition/documentation concents.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: A participant who has attested to the accuracy of the composition/document.

annotation.definition: The type of attestation the authenticator offers.
annotation.comment: Use more than one code where a single attestor has more than one mode (professional and legal are often paired).
annotation.requirements: Indicates the level of officialness of the attestation.

annotation.definition: When composition was attested by the party.
annotation.requirements: Identifies when the information in the composition was deemed accurate. (Things may have changed since then.).

annotation.definition: Who attested the composition in the specified way.
annotation.requirements: Identifies who has taken on the responsibility for accuracy of the composition content.
annotation.rimMapping: ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and isNormalEntity()] or ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole and not(player)]/scoper[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="ORG" and isNormalEntity()]

binding.name: DocumentConfidentiality
binding.definition: Codes specifying the level of confidentiality of the composition

binding.name: CompositionSectionType
binding.definition: Classification of a composition / document

binding.name: CompositionStatus
binding.definition: The workflow/clinical status of the composition

code.definition: This is an preliminary composition or document (also known as initial or interim). The content may be incomplete or unverified.
The composition or document is complete and verified by an appropriate person, and no further work is planned.

The composition or document has been modified subsequent to being released as "final", and is complete and verified by an authorised person. The modifications added new information to the composition or document, but did not revise existing content.
The composition or document has been modified subsequent to being released as "final", and is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The composition or document was originally created/issued in error, and this is an amendment that marks that the entire series should not be considered as valid.

binding.name: DocumentType
binding.definition: Type of a composition

binding.name: CompositionAttestationMode
binding.definition: The way in which a person authenticated a composition

code.definition: The person authenticated the content in their personal capacity.
The person authenticated the content in their professional capacity.
The person authenticated the content and accepted legal responsibility for its content.
The organization authenticated the content as consistent with their policies and procedures.

binding.name: DocumentEventType
binding.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented

annotation.definition: Logical Identifier for the composition, assigned when created. This identifier stays constant as the composition is changed over time.
annotation.comment: see discussion in resource definition for how these relate.

annotation.definition: The composition editing time, when the composition was last logically changed by the author.
annotation.comment: The Last Modified Date on the composition may be after the instant of the document was attested without being changed.
annotation.requirements: instant is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

annotation.definition: Specifies the particular kind of composition (e.g. History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Progress Note). This usually equates to the purpose of making the composition.
annotation.requirements: Key metadata element describing the composition, used in searching/filtering.

annotation.definition: A categorisation for the type of the composition. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Composition Type.
annotation.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the composition is of interest when viewing an index of compositions or documents.

annotation.definition: Official human-readable label for the composition.
annotation.comment: If compositions do not have a title, the text or a display name of Composition.type (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note") can be used in it's place.

annotation.shortDefinition: preliminary | final | appended | amended | entered in error
annotation.definition: The workflow/clinical status of this composition. The status is a marker for the clinical standing of the document.
annotation.comment: If a composition is marked as withdrawn, the compositions/documents in the series, or data from the composition or document series, should never be displayed to a user without being clearly marked as untrustworthy. The flag "withdrawn" is why this element is labeled as a modifier of other elements.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to mark interim, amended, or withdrawn compositions or documents.

annotation.definition: The code specifying the level of confidentiality of the Composition.
annotation.comment: The exact use of this element, and enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are out of scope for FHIR, and delegated to implementation profiles (see security section).

annotation.definition: Who or what the composition is about. The composition can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).
annotation.comment: For clinical documents, this is usually the patient.
annotation.requirements: Essential metadata for searching for the composition, identifies who/what the composition/document is about.

annotation.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in the composition. (Not necessarily who typed it in.).
annotation.requirements: Identifies who is responsible for the content.

annotation.definition: A participant who has attested to the accuracy of the composition/document.
annotation.comment: Only list each attester once.
annotation.requirements: Identifies responsibility for the accuracy of the composition content.

annotation.definition: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the composition/document information.
annotation.comment: This is useful when documents are derived from a composition - provides guidance for how to get the latest version of the document. This is optional because knowing this is sometimes not known by the authoring system, and can be inferred by context. However it's important that this information be known when working with a derived document, so providing a custodian is encouraged.
annotation.requirements: Identifies where to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc.

annotation.definition: The main event/act/item, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented.
annotation.comment: The event needs to be consistent with the type element, though can provide further information if desired.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for the composition and creates a linkage between a resource describing an event and the composition created describing the event.

annotation.definition: Describes the clinical encounter or type of care this documentation is associated with.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for the composition and supports searching.
annotation.rimMapping: unique(highest(./outboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()], priorityNumber)/target[moodCode="EVN" and classCode=("ENC", "PCPR") and isNormalAct])

annotation.definition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

search.name: author
search.description: Who/what authored the composition

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: attester
search.description: Who attested the composition

search.name: subject
search.description: Who/what the composition is about

search.name: section-content
search.description: The actual data for the section

search.name: context
search.description: Code(s) that apply to the event being documented

search.name: class
search.description: Categorisation of Composition

search.name: section-type
search.description: Classification of section (recommended)

search.name: type
search.description: Kind of composition (LOINC if possible)

search.name: identifier
search.description: Logical identifier of composition (version-independent)

search.name: instant
search.description: Composition editing time

annotations.shortDefinition: A statement of relationships from one set of concepts to one or more other concept systems
annotations.definition: A statement of relationships from one set of concepts to one or more other concept systems.
A nested type in ConceptMap: Targets mapped to this concept.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this code is not for use as a real concept
annotation.definition: If this code is not for use as a real concept.
annotation.comment: Should be a version specific reference.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text to Display to the user
annotation.definition: Text to Display to the user.

annotation.shortDefinition: equal | equivalent | wider | narrower | inexact | unmatched | disjoint
annotation.definition: equal | equivalent | wider | narrower | inexact | unmatched | disjoint.
Description of status/issues in mapping.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ConceptMap: Mappings for a concept.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name for this concept (if just a group)
annotation.definition: Name for this concept (if just a group).

annotation.shortDefinition: System that defines the concept being mapped
annotation.definition: System that defines the concept being mapped.
Identifies concept being mapped.
Targets mapped to this concept.
annotation.comment: Ideally there would only be one map, with equal or equivalent mapping. But multiple maps are allowed for several narrower options, or to assert that other concepts are unmatched.

annotation.definition: Mappings for sub concepts.

binding.name: ConceptMapEquivalence
binding.definition: The degree of equivalence between concepts

code.definition: The definitions of the concepts are exactly the same (i.e. only grammatical differences) and structural implications of meaning are identifical or irrelevant (i.e. intensionally identical).
The definitions of the concepts mean the same thing (including when structural implications of meaning are considered) (i.e. extensionally identical).
The target mapping is wider in meaning than the source concept.

The target mapping is narrower in meaning that the source concept. The sense in which the mapping is narrower SHALL be described in the comments in this case, and applications should be careful when atempting to use these mappings operationally.

The target mapping overlaps with the source concept, but both source and target cover additional meaning. The sense in which the mapping is narrower SHALL be described in the comments in this case, and applications should be careful when atempting to use these mappings operationally.
There is no match for this concept in the destination concept system.
This is an explicit assertion that there is no mapping between the source and target concept.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id to reference this concept map
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this concept map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique OID, UUID, or URI).

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the concept map
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the concept map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
annotation.comment: There may be multiple resource versions of the concept map that have this same identifier.

annotation.shortDefinition: Informal name for this concept map
annotation.definition: A free text natural language name describing the concept map.
annotation.comment: Not expected to be unique.
annotation.requirements: Support human navigation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
annotation.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the concept map.
annotation.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
annotation.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the conept map. May also allow for contact.

annotation.definition: Contacts of the publisher to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
annotation.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Human language description of the concept map
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the use of the concept map - reason for definition, conditions of use, etc.
annotation.comment: The description is not intended to describe the semantics of the concept map. The description should capture its intended use, which is needed for ensuring integrity for its use in models across future changes.
annotation.requirements: Human understandibility.

annotation.shortDefinition: About the concept map or its content
annotation.definition: A copyright statement relating to the concept map and/or its contents.
annotation.comment: Frequently, the copyright differs between the concept map, and codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.

annotation.definition: The status of the concept map.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of ConceptMaps that are appropriate for use vs. not.
annotation.requirements: Identify when/if the concept map should be used.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: This ConceptMap was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of ConceptMaps that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.definition: The date that the concept map status was last changed.
annotation.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the concept map.
annotation.requirements: Need to know when a concept map was first legal for use or became withdrawn or replaced.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifies the source value set which is being mapped
annotation.definition: The source value set that specifies the concepts that are being mapped.
annotation.comment: Should be a version specific reference.

annotation.definition: The target value set provides context to the mappings. Note that the mapping is made between concepts, not between value sets, but the value set provides important context about how the concept mapping choices are made.
Mappings for a concept.

search.name: system
search.description: The system for any destination concepts mapped by this map

search.name: source
search.description: The system for any concepts mapped by this concept map

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: status
search.description: Status of the concept map

search.name: description
search.description: Text search in the description of the concept map

search.name: name
search.description: Name of the concept map

search.name: target
search.description: Provides context to the mappings

search.name: date
search.description: The concept map publication date

search.name: identifier
search.description: The identifier of the concept map

search.name: publisher
search.description: Name of the publisher of the concept map

search.name: version
search.description: The version identifier of the concept map

annotations.shortDefinition: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses
annotations.definition: Use to record detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses recognized by a clinician. There are many uses including: recording a Diagnosis during an Encounter; populating a problem List or a Summary Statement, such as a Discharge Summary.
annotations.todo:
* Age is questionable, you might well need a range of Age or even (in practice)
a text like "in their teens". => new ballot comment.
* Todo: discuss the applicability of assessing stages
* Change the description: it is circular.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events that are related in some way to this condition, or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition.

annotation.definition: The type of relationship that this condition has to the related item.

annotation.shortDefinition: Relationship target by means of a predefined code
annotation.definition: Code that identifies the target of this relationship. The code takes the place of a detailed instance target.
Target of the relationship.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed.

annotation.definition: A manifestation or symptom that led to the recording of this condition.
Links to other relevant information, including pathology reports.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.

annotation.definition: A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific.
Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based.
annotation.todo: When an assessment resource / framework is developed, this will be changed from Any to something narrower.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.

annotation.definition: Code that identifies the structural location.
annotation.comment: May include laterality.

annotation.definition: Detailed anatomical location information.

binding.name: ConditionCategory
binding.definition: A category assigned to the condition. E.g. finding | Condition | diagnosis | concern | condition

binding.name: ConditionKind
binding.definition: Identification of the Condition or diagnosis.

binding.name: ConditionStatus
binding.definition: The clinical status of the Condition or diagnosis

code.definition: This is a tentative diagnosis - still a candidate that is under consideration.
The patient is being treated on the basis that this is the condition, but it is still not confirmed.
There is sufficient diagnostic and/or clinical evidence to treat this as a confirmed condition.
This condition has been ruled out by diagnostic and clinical evidence.

binding.name: ConditionCertainty
binding.definition: The degree of confidence that this condition is correct

binding.name: ConditionRelationshipType
binding.definition: The type of relationship between a condition and its related item

code.definition: this condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance and is a consequence of it.
code.comment: The consequence may be good or bad

code.definition: this condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance, but it is not known whether they are causually linked.
code.comment: This condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance, but may or may not be a consequence (i.e. causually linked)

binding.name: ConditionSeverity
binding.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this condition that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL refernce to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

annotation.definition: Subject of this condition.
Encounter during which the condition was first asserted.
Person who takes responsibility for asserting the existence of the condition as part of the electronic record.
Estimated or actual date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first detected/suspected.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
annotation.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.
A category assigned to the condition. E.g. finding | Condition | diagnosis | concern | condition.
annotation.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts.
annotation.v2Mapping: 'problem' if from PRB-3. 'diagnosis' if from DG1 segment in PV1 message

annotation.definition: The clinical status of the condition.
The degree of confidence that this condition is correct.
annotation.comment: May be a percentage.

annotation.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
annotation.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: Estimated or actual date, or age
annotation.definition: Estimated or actual date the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician.
annotation.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur.

annotation.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
annotation.comment:
There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.
If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid.

annotation.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.
Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed.
annotation.comment: The evidence may be a simple lost of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both.

annotation.definition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.
annotation.comment: May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

annotation.shortDefinition: Causes or precedents for this Condition
annotation.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events that are related in some way to this condition, or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition.
annotation.comment: Although a condition may be caused by a substance, this is not intended to be used to record allergies/adverse reactions to substances.
annotation.v2Mapping: could infer from presence of multiple PRB segments in a PPR message that the problems are related, but not clear how to communicate the nature of the relationship

annotation.definition: Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis.

search.name: asserter
search.description: Person who asserts this condition

search.name: status
search.description: The status of the condition

search.name: location
search.description: Location - may include laterality

search.name: subject
search.description: Subject of this condition

search.name: onset
search.description: When the Condition started (if started on a date)

search.name: severity
search.description: The severity of the condition

search.name: code
search.description: Code for the condition

search.name: encounter
search.description: Encounter when condition first asserted

search.name: date-asserted
search.description: When first detected/suspected/entered

search.name: stage
search.description: Simple summary (disease specific)

search.name: related-code
search.description: Relationship target by means of a predefined code

search.name: category
search.description: The category of the condition

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: related-item
search.description: Relationship target resource

annotations.shortDefinition: A conformance statement
annotations.definition: A conformance statement about how an application or implementation supports FHIR or the set of requirements for a desired implementation.
annotations.rimMapping: N/A (would map to MIF instead, but MIF has no equivalent)

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Describes the software that is covered by this conformance statement. Used when the profile describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

annotation.definition: Name software is known by.
Version covered by this statement.
annotation.comment: If possible, version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

annotation.definition: Date this version of the software released.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Defines the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.

annotation.definition: Identifies whether this portion of the statement is describing ability to initiate or receive restful operations.
Provides documentation about the system's restful capabilities that apply across all applications, such as security.
annotation.todo: Ballot Question: Do we need something more formal for security capabilities?.

annotation.definition: Information about security of implementation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Resource served on the REST interface
annotation.definition: Identifies the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.
annotation.comment: Max of one repetition per resource type.

annotation.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.
Definition of a named query and its parameters and their meaning.

A list of profiles that this server implements for accepting documents on mailbox. If the list is empty, then documents are not accepted. The base specification has the profile identifier "http://hl7.org/fhir/documents/mailbox". Other specifications can declare their own identifier for this use.
annotation.comment: If a server accepts messages on the /Mailbox end-point, it declares this in the messaging elements.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Describes the messaging capabilities of the solution.

annotation.definition: The address to which messages and/or replies are to be sent.
annotation.comment: Can be just an identifier for solutions that do not use network addresses for routing.

annotation.definition: The length if the receiver's reliable messaging cache length (if a receiver) or how long the cache length on the receiver should be (if a sender).
annotation.comment: If this value is missing then the application does not implement (receiver) or depend on (sender) reliable messaging.

annotation.definition: Provides documentation about the system's messaging capabilities for this endpoint not otherwise documented by the conformance statement. For example, process for becoming an authorized messaging exchange partner.
Describes the solution's support for an event at this end point.
annotation.comment: The same event may be listed up to two times - once as sender and once as receiver.
annotation.todo: Need to add follow-ups and need to do more to flesh out messaging dynamic model.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Used when the statement describes the capabilities of a specific implementation instance - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.

annotation.definition: Information about the specific installation that this conformance statement relates to.
The base URL for the implementation. This forms the base for REST interfaces as well as the mailbox and document interfaces.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.

annotation.shortDefinition: A resource type that is supported
annotation.definition: Identifies the resource exposed via the restful interface.
Identifies the profile that describes the solution's support for the resource, including any constraints on cardinality, bindings, lengths or other limitations.
annotation.comment: This profile applies to all the resources of this type - i.e. it is the superset of what is supported.
annotation.todo: Ballot: Does a system need to be able to enumerate profiles that it does support?.

annotation.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether vRead can return past versions
annotation.definition: A flag for whether the server is able to return past versions as part of the vRead operation.
annotation.comment: It is useful to support the vRead operation for current operations, even if past versions aren't available.

annotation.shortDefinition: If allows/uses update to a new location
annotation.definition: If the update operation is used (client) or allowed (server) to a new location where a resource doesn't already exist. This means that the server allows the client to create new identities on the server.
annotation.comment: Allowing the clients to create new identities on the server means that the system administrator needs to have confidence that the clients do not create clashing identities between them. Obviously, there is only one client, this won't happen. While creating identities on the client means that the clients need to be managed, it's much more convenient for many scenarios.

annotation.definition: _include values supported by the server.
annotation.comment: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes.

annotation.definition: Defines additional search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

annotation.shortDefinition: read | vread | update | delete | history-instance | validate | history-type | create | search-type
annotation.definition: Identifies which operation is supported.

Provides guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as 'delete is a logical delete' or 'updates are only allowed with version id' or 'creates permitted from pre-authorized certificates only'.
annotation.requirements: REST allows a degree of variability in the implementation of RESTful solutions that is useful for exchange partners to be aware of.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Describes the solution's support for an event at this end point.

annotation.definition: Identifies the supported messaging event.
annotation.todo: May need profile id as well if profiles can define message events.

annotation.definition: The impact of the content of the message.
The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver.
Identifies the messaging transport protocol(s) supported by this endpoint.
annotation.todo: Loosen this to "extensible" once tooling supports that.

annotation.definition: Identifies the resource associated with the event. This is the resource that defines the event.
annotation.comment: This SHALL be provided if the event type supports multiple different resource types.

annotation.definition: Information about the request for this event.
Information about the response for this event.
Guidance on how this event is handled, such as internal system trigger points, business rules, etc.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Certificates associated with security profiles.

annotation.definition: Mime type for certificate.
Actual certificate.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

annotation.definition: Identifies which system operation is supported.
Provides guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as limitations on the kind of transactions allowed, or information about system wide search is implemented.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Definition of a named query and its parameters and their meaning.

annotation.definition: The name of this query, which is used in the _query parameter when the query is used.
Description of the query - the functionality it offers, and considerations about how it functions and to use it.
Parameter for the named query.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A document definition.

annotation.definition: The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver.
Describes how the application supports or uses the specified document profile. For example, when are documents created, what action is taken with consumed documents, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Constraint on a resource used in the document
annotation.definition: Constraint on a resource used in the document.
annotation.comment: The first resource is the document resource.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Information about security of implementation.

annotation.definition: Server adds CORS headers when responding to reuqests - this enables javascript applications to yuse the server.
annotation.comment: The easiest CORS headers to add are Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * & Access-Control-Request-Method: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.

annotation.definition: What type of security services are supported/required.

annotation.shortDefinition: General description of how security works
annotation.definition: General description of how security works.
Certificates associated with security profiles.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Defines additional search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of.

annotation.definition: Corresponds to the name of the standard or custom search parameter.
annotation.comment: Parameter names cannot overlap with standard parameter names, and standard parameters cannot be redefined.

annotation.definition: A formal reference to where this parameter was first defined, so that a client can be confident of the meaning of the search parameter.
annotation.comment: This SHOULD be populated for all search parameters not defined as custom search extensions. The uri for a search parameter defined in the specification itself is http://hl7.org/fhir/[resource]/search#[name].

annotation.shortDefinition: number | date | string | token | reference | composite
annotation.definition: The type of value a search parameter refers to, and how the content is interpreted.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contents and meaning of search parameter
annotation.definition: For standard parameters, provides additional information on how the parameter is used in this solution. For custom parameters, provides a description of what the parameter does.

annotation.shortDefinition: XPath that extracts the parameter set
annotation.definition: An XPath expression that extracts the set of elements that contain values that a search parameter matches.
annotation.comment: Note that the elements are sometimes complex elements where logic is required to determine quite how to handle them. E.g. CodeableConcepts may contain text and/or multiple codings, where the codings themselves contain a code and a system.

annotation.shortDefinition: Types of resource (if a resource reference)
annotation.definition: Types of resource (if a resource reference).
Chained names supported.

binding.name: DocumentMode
binding.definition: Whether the application produces or consumes documents

code.definition: The application produces documents of the specified type.
The application consumes documents of the specified type.

binding.name: RestfulConformanceMode
binding.definition: The mode of a RESTful conformance statement

code.definition: The application acts as a server for this resource.
The application acts as a client for this resource.

binding.name: MessageTransport
binding.definition: The protocol used for message transport

code.definition: The application sends or receives messages using HTTP POST (may be over http or https).
The application sends or receives messages using File Transfer Protocol.
The application sends or receivers messages using HL7's Minimal Lower Level Protocol.

binding.name: ConformanceEventMode
binding.definition: The mode of a message conformance statement

code.definition: The application sends requests and receives responses.
The application receives requests and sends responses.

binding.name: MessageSignificanceCategory
binding.definition: The impact of the content of a message

code.definition: The message represents/requests a change that should not be processed more than once. E.g. Making a booking for an appointment.
The message represents a response to query for current information. Retrospective processing is wrong and/or wasteful.
The content is not necessarily intended to be current, and it can be reprocessed, though there may be version issues created by processing old notifications.

binding.name: RestfulOperationType
binding.definition: Operations supported by REST at the type or instance level

binding.name: ConformanceStatementStatus
binding.definition: The status of this conformance statement

code.definition: This conformance statement is still under development.
This conformance statement is ready for use in production systems.
This conformance statement has been withdrawn or superceded and should no longer be used.

binding.name: RestfulOperationSystem
binding.definition: Operations supported by REST at the system level

binding.name: SearchParamType
binding.definition: Data types allowed to be used for search parameters

code.definition: Search parameter SHALL be a number (an whole number, or a decimal).
Search parameter is on a date/time. The date format is the standard XML format, though other formats may be supported.
Search parameter is a simple string, like a name part. Search is case-insensitive and accent-insensitive. May match just the start of a string. String parameters may contain spaces.

Search parameter on a coded element or identifier. May be used to search through the text, displayname, code and code/codesystem (for codes) and label, system and key (for identifier). Its value is either a string or a pair of namespace and value, separated by a "|", depending on the modifier used.
A reference to another resource.
A composite search parameter that combines a search on two values together.

binding.name: RestfulSecurityService
binding.definition: Types of security services used with FHIR

code.definition: OAuth (see oauth.net).
OAuth version 2 (see oauth.net).
Microsoft NTLM Authentication.
Basic authentication defined in HTTP specification.
see http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4120.txt.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id to reference this statement
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique OID, UUID, or URI).

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the statement
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
annotation.comment: There may be multiple resource versions of the conformance statement that have this same identifier.

annotation.shortDefinition: Informal name for this conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the conformance statement.
annotation.comment: Not expected to be globally unique.

annotation.definition: Name of Organization.
Contacts for Organization relevant to this conformance statement. May be website, email, phone numbers, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Human description of the conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the conformance statement and its use. Typically, this is used when the profile describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
annotation.comment: This field can be used for things such as why the confomrance statement was written, comments about its context etc. This does not need to be populated when the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

annotation.definition: The status of this conformance statement.
annotation.comment: This is not intended for use with actual conformance statements, but where conformance statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: This conformance statement was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of conformance statements that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.definition: Date that the conformance statement is published.

annotation.shortDefinition: Software that is covered by this conformance statement
annotation.definition: Describes the software that is covered by this conformance statement. Used when the profile describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this describes a specific instance
annotation.definition: Used when the statement describes the capabilities of a specific implementation instance - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.
The version of the FHIR specification on which this conformance statement is based.

annotation.shortDefinition: True if application accepts unknown elements
annotation.definition: Whether the application accepts unknown non-"must understand" elements as part of a resource. This does not include extensions, but genuine new additions to a resource.
The formats supported by this implementation.
annotation.comment: "xml" or "json" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

annotation.definition: A list of profiles supported by the system. Supported by the system means for a server, that the system hosts/produces a set of resources that conform to a particular profile, that it allows clients to search by this profile, and that these will find the appropriate data. For a client, it means that the client will search by this profile, and process the data following the guidance implicit in the profile.
annotation.comment:
Supported profiles are different to the profiles that apply to a particular resource in rest.resource.profile. The resource profile is a general statement of what features of the resource are supported overall by the system - the sum total of the facilities it supports. A supported profile is a deeper statement about the functionality of the data and services provided by the server (or used by the client). A typical case is a laboratory system that produces a set of different reports- this is the list of types of data that it publishes. A key aspect of declaring profiles here is the question of how the client converts knowledge that the server publishes this data into working with the data; the client can inspect individual resources to determine whether they conform to a particular profile, but how does it find the ones that does? It does so by searching using the _profile parameter, so any resources listed here must be valid values for the _profile resource (using the identifier in the target profile).
Typical supported profiles cross resource types to describe a network of related resources, so they are listed here rather than by resource. However they do not need to describe more than one resource.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the endpoint is a RESTful one
annotation.definition: Defines the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow definition of both client and server behaviors or possibly behaviors under different configuration settings (for software or requirements statements).

annotation.definition: Describes the messaging capabilities of the solution.
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow the documentation of multiple endpoints per solution.

annotation.definition: A document definition.

invariant.human: SHALL have at least one of description, software, or implementation
A Conformance statement SHALL have at least one of rest, messaging or document
The set of documents must be unique by the combination of profile & mode
The set of end points listed for messaging must be unique
If there is more than one messaging element, endpoint must be specified for all
There can only be one REST declaration per mode

annotations.shortDefinition: An instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare
annotations.definition: This resource identifies an instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare without being substantially changed through that activity. The device may be a machine, an insert, a computer, an application, etc. This includes durable (reusable) medical equipment as well as disposable equipment used for diagnostic, treatment, and research for healthcare and public health.
annotations.requirements: Allows institutions to track their devices.

binding.name: DeviceKind
binding.definition: Defines the nature of the device and the kind of functionality/services/behavior that may be expected from it

annotation.shortDefinition: Instance id from manufacturer, owner and others
annotation.definition: Identifiers assigned to this device by various organizations. The most likely organizations to assign identifiers are the manufacturer and the owner, though regulatory agencies may also assign an identifier. The identifiers identify the particular device, not the kind of device.
annotation.comment: Often fixed to the device as a barcode. May include names given to the device in local usage. Note that some of the barcodes affixed to the device identify it's type, not it's instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of device this is
annotation.definition: Describes what kind of device that this.
The name of the manufacturer.

annotation.shortDefinition: Model id assigned by the manufacturer
annotation.definition: The "model" - an identifier assigned by the manufacturer to identify the product by its type. This number is shared by the all devices sold as the same type.
The version of the device, if the device has multiple releases under the same model, or if the device is software or carries firmware.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date of expiry of this device (if applicable)
annotation.definition: Date of expiry of this device (if applicable).

FDA Mandated Unique Device Identifier. Use the human readable information (the content that the user sees, which is sometimes different to the exact syntax represented in the barcode) - see http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/UniqueDeviceIdentification/default.htm.
annotation.comment: The unique identifier may identify an instance of a device uniquely, or it may just identify the type of the device. A portion of the UDI - the DI part - can be extracted from the UDI when required, and used to look up information about the device through the GUDID.

annotation.definition: Lot number of manufacture.
annotation.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

annotation.definition: The organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.
The resource may be found in a literal location (i.e. GPS coordinates), a logical place (i.e. "in/with the patient"), or a coded location.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the resource is affixed to a person
annotation.definition: If the resource is affixed to a person.
Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
annotation.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

annotation.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
annotation.comment: if the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should be the root URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

search.name: organization
search.description: The organization responsible for the device

search.name: model
search.description: The model of the device

search.name: patient
search.description: If the resource is affixed to a person

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: location
search.description: Where the resource is found

search.name: manufacturer
search.description: The manufacturer of the device

search.name: udi
search.description: FDA Mandated Unique Device Identifier

search.name: type
search.description: The type of the device

search.name: identifier
search.description: Instance id from manufacturer, owner and others

annotations.definition: Describes the data produced by a device at a point in time.
A nested type in DeviceObservationReport: A medical-related subsystem of a medical device.

annotation.definition: Describes the compartment.
Groups together physiological measurement data and derived data.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DeviceObservationReport: A piece of measured or derived data that is reported by the machine.

annotation.definition: The data for the metric.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DeviceObservationReport: Groups together physiological measurement data and derived data.

annotation.definition: Describes the channel.

annotation.shortDefinition: Piece of data reported by device
annotation.definition: A piece of measured or derived data that is reported by the machine.

annotation.definition: The point in time that the values are reported.

annotation.definition: An identifier assigned to this observation bu the source device that made the observation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifies/describes where the data came from
annotation.definition: Identification information for the device that is the source of the data.
The subject of the measurement.

annotation.shortDefinition: A medical-related subsystem of a medical device
annotation.definition: A medical-related subsystem of a medical device.

annotations.shortDefinition: A request for a diagnostic service
annotations.definition: A request for a diagnostic investigation service to be performed.

A nested type in DiagnosticOrder: The specific diagnostic investigations that are requested as part of this request. Sometimes, there can only be one item per request, but in most contexts, more than one investigation can be requested.

annotation.definition: A code that identifies a particular diagnostic investigation that has been requested.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this item relates to specific specimens
annotation.definition: If the item is related to a specific speciment.
annotation.comment: A single specimen should not appear in both DIagnosticOrder.specimen and DiagnosticOrder.item.specimen.

annotation.definition: Anatomical location where the request test should be performed.

annotation.shortDefinition: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status of this individual item within the order.
annotation.comment: If the request has multiple items that have their own life cycles, then the items will have their own status while the overall diagnostic order is (usually) "in progress".

annotation.definition: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as this item of the request is processed.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DiagnosticOrder: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as the request is processed.

annotation.shortDefinition: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status for the event.

annotation.shortDefinition: The date at which the event happened
annotation.definition: The date/time at which the event occurred.
The person who was responsible for performing or recording the action.

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderStatus
binding.definition: The status of a diagnostic order

code.definition: The request has been placed.
The receiving system has received the order, but not yet decided whether it will be performed.
The receiving system has accepted the order, but work has not yet commenced.
The work to fulfill the order is happening.
The work is complete, and the outcomes are being reviewed for approval.
The work has been complete, the report(s) released, and no further work is planned.
The request has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to fulfill the request.
The diagnostic investigation was attempted, but due to some procedural error, it could not be completed.

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderPriority
binding.definition: The clinical priority of a diagnostic order

code.definition: The order has no particular priority with it.
The order should be urgently.
The order is time-critical.

annotation.definition: Who or what the investigation is to be performed on. This is usually a human patient, but diagnostic tests can also be requested on animals, groups of humans or animals, devices such as dialysis machines, or even locations (typically for environmental scans).
The practitioner that holds legal responsibility for ordering the investigation.
Identifiers assigned to this order by the order or by the receiver.

annotation.shortDefinition: The encounter that this diagnostic order is associated with
annotation.definition: An encounter that provides additional informaton about the healthcare context in which this request is made.
An explanation or justification for why this diagnostic investigation is being requested.
annotation.comment: This may be used to decide how the diagnostic investigation will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the whole order relates to specific specimens
annotation.definition: One or more specimens that the diagnostic investigation is about.
annotation.comment: Many investigation requests will create a need for specimens, but the request itself is not actually about the specimens. This is provided for when the diagnostic investigation is requested on already existing specimens.

annotation.shortDefinition: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status of the order.
annotation.comment: Typically the system placing the order sets the status to requested. There after, the order is maintained by the receiver that updates the status as the request is handled.

annotation.definition: The clinical priority associated with this order.
annotation.comment: The Order resource also has a priority. Generally, these should be the same, but they can be different, for instance in the case where the clinician indicates that the order is urgent, but the subsequent workflow process overrule this priority for some reason. The effective default value is "normal".

annotation.shortDefinition: A list of events of interest in the lifecycle
annotation.definition: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as the request is processed.
annotation.comment: This is not the same as an audit trail - it is a view of the important things that happened in the past. Typically, there would only be one entry for any given status, and systems may not record all the status events.

annotation.definition: The specific diagnostic investigations that are requested as part of this request. Sometimes, there can only be one item per request, but in most contexts, more than one investigation can be requested.
annotation.comment: There would always be at least one item in normal usage, but this is optional so that a workflow can quote order details without having to list the items.

search.name: orderer
search.description: Who ordered the test

search.name: past-status
search.description: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed

search.description: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed

search.description: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed

search.description: Who/what test is about

search.description: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | on hold | rejected | failed

search.description: The encounter that this diagnostic order is associated with

search.name: actor
search.description: Who recorded or did this

search.name: code
search.description: Code for this item

search.name: date
search.description: The date at which the event happened

search.name: status-date
search.description: A combination of past-status and date

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: bodysite
search.description: Location of requested test (if applicable)

search.name: item-date
search.description: The date at which the event happened

search.name: specimen
search.description: If the whole order relates to specific specimens

search.name: item-status-date
search.description: A combination of item-past-status and item-date

search.name: identifier
search.description: Identifiers assigned to this order

annotations.shortDefinition: A Diagnostic report - a combination of request information, atomic results, images, interpretation, and formatted reports
annotations.definition: The findings and interpretation of diagnostic tests performed on patients and/or specimens. The report includes clinical context such as requesting and provider information, and some mix of atomic results, images, textual and coded interpretation, and formatted representation of diagnostic reports.
annotations.comment: This is intended to capture a single report,and is not suitable for use in displaying summary information that covers multiple reports. A typical example is a laboratory cumulative report format.
annotations.requirements: To support reporting for any diagnostic report into a clinical data repository.
annotations.committeeNotes: It's not clear how to handle cumulative reports.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DiagnosticReport: Details concerning a single pathology test requested.

annotation.definition: The encounter that this diagnostic investigation is associated with.
annotation.requirements: Some institutions track and file diagnostic reports under a specific encounter.

annotation.definition: The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester.
annotation.comment: Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued.

annotation.definition: The local ID assigned to the test order by the diagnostic service provider.
annotation.comment: Usually equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued.

annotation.definition: Identification of pathology test requested,.
annotation.comment: Useful where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to report what diagnostic test swere requested (not always the same as what is delivered).

annotation.definition: Anatomical location where the request test should be performed.
annotation.comment: This is often implicit or explicit in the requested test, and doesn't need to be specified if so.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBX-20-Observation Site (need to distinguish requested site from site actually performed at)

annotation.definition: Details of the clinician or organization requesting the diagnostic service.
annotation.requirements: The requesting clinician may need to be contacted concerning the method or interpretation of the diagnostic service, and is frequently used for billing purposes too.

annotation.definition: Details of the clinical information provided to the diagnostic service along with the original request.
annotation.requirements: Knowing the clinical information may influence the interpretation of the result.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-13-Relevant Clinical Information (could also be in NTE-3 or OBR-18, 19, 20, 21)

annotations.definition: A nested type in DiagnosticReport: A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some value in DiagnosticReport.resultGroup.name to describe what binds all the results together.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name/Code for this group of results
annotation.definition: A code or name that describes this group of results. For the base group, this is the report name.
annotation.comment: Examples of nested report groups: the antibody code for a goup of antibody related test, or the organism code for a group of isolate/sensitivities, or a set of perinatal measurements on a single fetus.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-4-Universal Service ID (V2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)

annotation.definition: Details about the individual specimen to which these 'Result group' test results refer.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to report information about the collected specimens on which the report is based.

annotation.definition: A sub-group in a report group. Sub groups can be grouped in arbitrary ways. The group.name defines the purpose and interpretation of the grouping.
annotation.comment: Nested report groups beyond the first level are not used often, but arise in structured pathology reports, and where there is more than one sensitivity assessment per discovered organism.

annotation.definition: Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements.
annotation.requirements: Need to report results with information that assist with interpretation.

binding.name: DiagnosticRequests
binding.definition: Codes for tests/services that can be performed by diagnostic services

binding.name: BodySite
binding.definition: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality

binding.name: AdjunctDiagnosis
binding.definition: Diagnoses codes provided as adjuncts to the report

binding.name: DiagnosticReportNames
binding.definition: Codes that describe Diagnostic Reports

binding.name: DiagnosticServiceSection
binding.definition: Codes for diagnostic service sections

binding.name: DiagnosticReportStatus
binding.definition: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole

code.definition: The existence of the report is registered, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) report: data in the report may be incomplete or unverified.
The report is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The report has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The report has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorised person, and data has been changed.
The report has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorised person. New content has been added, but existing content hasn't changed.
The report is unavailable because the measurement was not started or not completed (also sometimes called "aborted").
The report has been withdrawn following previous Final release.

annotation.definition: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications need to take appropriate action if a report is withdrawn.
annotation.requirements: Diagnostic services routinely issue provisional/incomplete reports, and sometimes withdraw previously released reports.
annotation.rimMapping:
statusCode
Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

annotation.definition: The date and/or time that this version of the report was released from the source diagnostic service.
annotation.comment: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.
annotation.requirements: Clinicians need to be able to check the date that the report was released.

annotation.definition: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.
annotation.requirements: SHALL know the subject context.
annotation.v2Mapping: PID-3-Patient ID List (no V2 mapping for Group or Device)

annotation.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
annotation.comment: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items - it's the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.
annotation.requirements: Need to know who to contact if there are queries about the results. Also may need to track the source of reports for secondary data analysis.

annotation.shortDefinition: Id for external references to this report
annotation.definition: The local ID assigned to the report by the order filler, usually by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider.
annotation.requirements: Need to know what identifier to use when making queries about this report from the source laboratory, and for linking to the report outside FHIR context.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-51-Observation Group ID (todo: check semantic intent of OBR-51 with OOWG)

annotation.definition: Details concerning a single pathology test requested.
annotation.comment: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single Pathology test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued and also to report what diagnostic tests were requested (not always the same as what is delivered).

annotation.definition: The section of the diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology, MRI.
annotation.requirements: Help clinicians filter/find the reports they are looking for.

annotation.shortDefinition: Diagnostically relevant time of diagnostic report
annotation.definition: The diagnostically relevant time for this report - that is, the point in time at which the observations that are reported in this diagnostic report relate to the patient.
annotation.comment: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was peformed. If there is specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.
annotation.requirements: Need to know where in the patient history to file/present this report.

annotation.definition: A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some value in DiagnosticReport.resultGroup.name to describe what binds all the results together.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - groups can can contain groups. The base group doesn't usually contain a group name, but nested groups always do.

annotation.shortDefinition: Key images associated with this report
annotation.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and maybe directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).
annotation.comment: An imaging study is a list of images following a DICOM specification - only list one of these, or multiple images.

annotation.definition: Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the diagnostic report.
annotation.comment: Typically, a report is either [all data, no narrative (e.g. Core lab)] or [a mix of data with some concluding narrative (e.g. Structured Pathology Report, Bone Density)], or [all narative (e.g. typical imaging report, histopathology)]. In all these cases, the narrative goes in "text".
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to provide a conclusion that is not lost amongst the basic result data.

annotation.definition: Codes for the conclusion.
Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
annotation.comment: Possible formats: text/html, text/plain, text/rtf, application/msword, application/pdf, application/rtf, application/vnd.oasis.opendocument.text, application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document. Application/pdf is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.
annotation.requirements: Laboratory needs to be able to provide its own fully formatted report for clinical fidelity.

example.name: Assorted Collection
example.description: Various reports gathered from v2 messages

example.name: Report Feed
example.description: Snapshot of a live feed from a laboratory

search.name: result
search.description: Link to an atomic result (observation resource)

search.name: requester
search.description: Who made a request that lead to the report

search.name: status
search.description: The status of the report

search.name: test
search.description: A test requested that the report is in response to

search.name: subject
search.description: The subject of the report

search.name: issued
search.description: When the report was issued

search.name: code
search.description: A coded diagnosis on the report

search.name: date
search.description: The clinically relevant time of the report

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: specimen
search.description: The specimen details

search.name: name
search.description: The name/code of the report

search.name: service
search.description: Which diagnostic discipline/department created the report

search.name: performer
search.description: Who was the source of the report (organization)

search.name: group
search.description: Name /code of a group in the report

search.name: identifier
search.description: An identifier for the report

annotations.shortDefinition: A manifest that defines a set of documents
annotations.definition: A manifest that defines a set of documents.

binding.name: DocumentSetType
binding.definition: Specifies the kind of a set of documents (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.). The type of a set of documents may be the same as one of the documents in it - especially if there's only one - but it may be wider

annotation.shortDefinition: Unique Identifier for the set of documents
annotation.definition: A single identifier that uniquely identifies this manifest. Principally used to refer to the manifest in non-FHIR contexts.
Other identifiers associated with the document, including version independent, source record and workflow related identifiers.
annotation.comment: Other identifiers can also include Identifiers may be Accession Numbers, Order Numbers, Referral Request Identifiers, XDS Workflow Instance Identifiers.

annotation.shortDefinition: The subject of the set of documents
annotation.definition: Who or what the set of documents is about. The documents can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure). If the documents cross more than one subject, then more than one subjecti allowed here (unusual use case).

annotation.shortDefinition: Intended to get notified about this set of documents
annotation.definition: A patient, practitioner, or organization that this set of documents is intended for.
annotation.comment: How the recipient receives the document set or is notified of it is up to the implementation. This element is just a statement of intent.

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of document set this is
annotation.definition: Specifies the kind of this set of documents (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.). The type of a set of documents may be the same as one of the documents in it - especially if there's only one - but it may be wider.
Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document.
annotation.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) it in or who was the source (informant).

annotation.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
annotation.comment: In some cases, the event is inherent in the type element, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act. An event can further specialize the act inherent in the type, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more event codes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the class or type elements as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.
