annotations.shortDefinition: Family History
annotations.definition: Significant health events and conditions for people related to the subject relevant in the context of care for the subject.

A nested type in FamilyHistory: The significant Conditions (or condition) that the family member had. This is a repeating section to allow a system to represent more than one condition per resource, though there is nothing stopping multiple resources - one per condition.

annotation.definition: The actual condition specified. Could be a coded condition (like MI or Diabetes) or a less specific string like 'cancer' depending on how much is known about the condition and the capabilities of the creating system.
Indicates what happened as a result of this condition. If the condition resulted in death, deceased date is captured on the relation.
Either the age of onset, range of approximate age or descriptive string can be recorded. For conditions with multiple occurrences, this describes the first known occurrence.
annotation.requirements: Age of onset of a condition in relatives is predictive of risk for the patient.

annotation.definition: An area where general notes can be placed about this specific condition.

annotations.definition: A nested type in FamilyHistory: The related person. Each FamilyHistory resource contains the entire family history for a single person.

annotation.definition: This will either be a name or a description. E.g. "Aunt Susan", "my cousin with the red hair".
annotation.requirements: Allows greater ease in ensuring the same person is being talked about.

annotation.definition: The type of relationship this person has to the patient (father, mother, brother etc.).
The actual or approximate date of birth of the relative.
annotation.requirements: Allows calculation of the relative's age.

annotation.definition: If this resource is indicating that the related person is deceased, then an indicator of whether the person is deceased (yes) or not (no) or the age or age range or description of age at death - can be indicated here. If the reason for death is known, then it can be indicated in the outcome code of the condition - in this case the deceased property should still be set.
annotation.rimMapping:
player[classCode=LIV, determinerCode=INSTANCE].deceasedInd, deceasedDate (could be URG)
For age, you'd hang an observation off the role

annotation.definition: This property allows a non condition-specific note to the made about the related person. Ideally, the note would be in the condition property, but this is not always possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: Condition that the related person had
annotation.definition: The significant Conditions (or condition) that the family member had. This is a repeating section to allow a system to represent more than one condition per resource, though there is nothing stopping multiple resources - one per condition.

binding.name: FamilialRelationship
binding.definition: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the related person being described in the family history

binding.name: ConditionOutcome
binding.definition: The result of the condition for the patient. E.g. death, permanent disability, temporary disability, etc.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this family history record that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL refernce to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

annotation.definition: The person who this history concerns.
Conveys information about family history not specific to individual relations.
The related person. Each FamilyHistory resource contains the entire family history for a single person.

example.name: Mother
example.description: Mother died from a stroke aged 56. Brother with diabetes.

annotations.shortDefinition: Group of multiple entities
annotations.definition: Represents a defined collection of entities that may be discussed or acted upon collectively but which are not expected to act collectively and are not formally or legally recognized. I.e. A collection of entities that isn't an Organization.
annotations.todo: We need determiner codes that indicate we're talking about a group even when we haven't specified a specific quantity.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Group: Identifies the traits shared by members of the group.

annotation.definition: A code that identifies the kind of trait being asserted.
annotation.requirements: Need a formal way of identifying the characteristic being described.

annotation.definition: The value of the trait that holds (or does not hold - see 'exclude') for members of the group.
annotation.comment: For Range, it means members of the group have a value that falls somewhere within the specified range.
annotation.requirements: The value of the characteristic is what determines group membership.

annotation.definition: If true, indicates the characteristic is one that is NOT held by members of the group.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications cannot wrongly include excluded members as included or vice versa.
annotation.requirements: Sometimes group membership is determined by characteristics not possessed.

person: ./classCode="PSN"
animal: ./classCode="ANM"
device: ./classCode="DEV"
medication: ./classCode="MMAT" and ./playedRole[isNormalRole() and classCode="THER"]
food: ./classCode="FOOD"
annotation.committeeNotes: Do we need "mixed" groups?.

annotation.definition: If true, indicates that the resource refers to a specific group of real individuals. If false, the group defines a set of intended individuals.
annotation.requirements: There are use-cases for groups that define specific collections of individuals, and other groups that define "types" of intended individuals. The requirements for both kinds of groups are similar, so we use a single resource, distinguished by this flag.

annotation.definition: Provides a specific type of resource the group includes. E.g. "cow", "syringe", etc.
annotation.comment: This would generally be omitted for Person resources.

annotation.definition: A label assigned to the group for human identification and communication.

annotation.requirements: Group size is a common defining characteristic.

annotation.definition: Identifies the traits shared by members of the group.
annotation.requirements: Needs to be a generic mechanism for identifying what individuals can be part of a group.
annotation.rimMapping: ./playedRole[isNormalRole()]/participation[isNormalParticipation() and typeCode="SBJ"]/act[isNormalAct and classCode="OBS" and moodCode="EVN"]

annotation.definition: Identifies the resource instances that are members of the group.
annotation.requirements: Often the only thing of interest about a group is "who's in it".

annotations.shortDefinition: Information summarized from a list of other resources
annotations.definition: A set of information summarized from a list of other resources.
annotations.todo:
RIM harmonization proposal to move LIST under GROUPER
RIM harmonization proposal to allow organizers to group roles as well as acts.

annotations.definition: A nested type in List: Entries in this list.

annotation.definition: The flag allows the system constructing the list to make one or more statements about the role and significance of the item in the list.
annotation.comment: The flag can only be understood in the context of the List.code. If the flag means that the entry has actually been deleted from the list, the deleted element SHALL be true. Deleted can only be used if the List.mode is "changes".
annotation.requirements: This field is present to support various clinical uses of lists, such as a discharge summary medication list, where flags specify whether the medication was added, modified, or deleted from the list.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this item is actually marked as deleted
annotation.definition: True if this item is marked as deleted in the list.
annotation.comment: If the flag means that the entry has actually been deleted from the list, the deleted element SHALL be true. Both flag and deleted can only be used if the List.mode is "changes". A deleted entry should be displayed in narrative as deleted.
annotation.requirements: The flag element may contain codes that an application processing the list does not understand. However there can be no ambiguity if a list item is actually marked as "deleted".

annotation.definition: When this item was added to the list.
annotation.comment: This is only useful and meaningful when the mode is "working".
annotation.requirements: The date may be significant for understanding the meaning of items in a working list.

annotation.definition: A reference to the actual resource from which data was derived.

binding.name: ListMode
binding.definition: The processing mode that applies to this list

code.definition: This list is the master list, maintained in an ongoing fashion with regular updates as the real world list it is tracking changes.
This list was prepared as a snapshot. It should not be assumed to be current.
The list is prepared as a statement of changes that have been made or recommended.

binding.name: ListItemFlag
binding.definition: Codes that provide further information about the reason and meaning of the item in the list

binding.name: ListPurpose
binding.definition: What the purpose of a list is

binding.name: ListEmptyReason
binding.definition: If a list is empty, why it is empty

annotation.shortDefinition: What the purpose of this list is
annotation.definition: This code defines the purpose of the list - why it was created.
annotation.comment: If there is no code, the purpose of the list is implied where it is used, such as in a document section using Document.section.code.
annotation.requirements: Lists often contain subsets of resources rather than an exhaustive list. The code identifies what type of subset is included.

annotation.shortDefinition: If all resources have the same subject
annotation.definition: The common subject (or patient) of the resources that are in the list, if there is one.
annotation.comment: Some purely aribitrary lists do not have a common subject, so this is optional.
annotation.requirements: The primary purpose of listing the subject explicitly it to help with finding the right list.

annotation.definition: The entity responsible for deciding what the contents of the list were.
annotation.comment: The primary and important source is the entity that made the decisions what items are in the list. This may be software or user.
annotation.requirements: Allows follow-up as well as context.

annotation.definition: The date that the list was prepared.
annotation.comment: The actual important date is the date of currency of the resources that were summarized, but it is usually assumed that these are current when the preparation occurs.
annotation.requirements: Identifies how current the list is which affects relevance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether items in the list have a meaningful order
annotation.definition: Whether items in the list have a meaningful order.
annotation.comment: Applications SHOULD render ordered lists in the order provided, but MAY allow users to re-order based on their own preferences as well. This is marked as "is modified" because whether the list is ordered or not has may change how the results are processed or displayed.
annotation.requirements: Important for presentation and rendering. Lists may be sorted to place more important information first or to group related entries.

annotation.definition: How this list was prepared - whether it is a working list that is suitable for being maintained in an ongoing basis, or if it represents a snapshot of a list of items from another source, or whether it is a prepared list where items may be marked as added, modified or deleted.
annotation.requirements: Lists are used in various ways, and it must be known in what way it is safe to use them.

annotation.definition: Entries in this list.
annotation.comment: If there are no entries in the list, an emptyReason SHOULD be provided.

annotation.definition: If the list is empty, why the list is empty.
annotation.comment: The various reasons for an empty list make a significant interpretation to its interpretation.
annotation.requirements: Allows capturing things like "none exist" or "not asked" which can be important for most lists.

invariant.human: The deleted flag can only be used if the mode of the list is "changes"

invariant.description: No emptyReason if list is not empty
invariant.human: A list can only have an emptyReason if it is empty

search.description: If all resources have the same subject

search.name: item
search.description: Actual entry

search.name: code
search.description: What the purpose of this list is

search.name: date
search.description: When the list was prepared

search.name: empty-reason
search.description: Why list is empty

annotation.shortDefinition: Unique code or number identifying the location to its users

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the location as used by humans
annotation.definition: Name of the location as used by humans. Needs not be unique.

annotation.definition: Description of the Location, which helps in finding or referencing the place.

annotation.shortDefinition: Indicates the type of function performed at the location
annotation.definition: Indicates the type of function performed at the location.
The contact details of the main communication devices present at the location.
Physical location.
annotation.requirements: If locations can be visited, we need to keep track of their address.

annotation.definition: Physical form of the location, e.g. building, room, vehicle, road.
annotation.requirements: For purposes of showing relevant locations in queries, we need to categorize locations.

annotation.definition: The absolute geographic location of the Location, expressed in a KML compatible manner (see notes below for KML).
annotation.requirements: For mobile applications and automated route-finding knowing the exact location of the Location is required.

annotation.shortDefinition: The organization that is responsible for the provisioning and upkeep of the location
annotation.definition: The organization that is responsible for the provisioning and upkeep of the location.
annotation.requirements: Need to know who manages the location.

annotation.definition: active | suspended | inactive.

annotation.shortDefinition: Another Location which this Location is physically part of
annotation.definition: Another Location which this Location is physically part of.
annotation.requirements: For purposes of location, display and identification, knowing which locations are located within other locations is important.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether a resource instance represents a specific location or a class of locations.
annotation.requirements: When using a Location resource for scheduling or orders, we need to be able to refer to a class of Locations instead of a specific Location.

Details of the type of the media - usually, how it was acquired (what type of device). If images sourced from a DICOM system, are wrapped in a Media resource, then this is the modality.

Identifiers associated with the image - these may include identifiers for the image itself, identifiers for the context of its collection (e.g. series ids) and context ids such as accession numbers or other workflow identifiers.
annotation.comment: The identifier label and use can be used to determine what kind of identifier it is.

annotation.definition: When the media was originally recorded. For video and audio, if the length of the recording is not insignificant, this is the end of the recording.
annotation.comment: For an image including multiple frames, this is the start time.

annotation.definition: Who/What this Media is a record of.

annotation.definition: The person who administered the collection of the image.

annotation.definition: The name of the imaging view e.g Lateral or Antero-posterior (AP).
The name of the device / manufacturer of the device that was used to make the recording.

annotation.shortDefinition: Height of the image in pixels(photo/video)
annotation.definition: Height of the image in pixels(photo/video).

annotation.shortDefinition: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video)
annotation.definition: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video).

The number of frames in a photo. This is used with a multi-page fax, or an imaging acquisition context that takes multiple slices in a single iamge, or an animated gif. If there is more than one frame, this SHALL have a value in order to alert interface software that a multi-frame capable rendering widget is required.
The length of the recording in seconds - for audio and video.
The actual content of the media - inline or by direct reference to the media source file.
annotation.comment: Recommended content types: image/jpeg, image/png, image/tiff, video/mpeg, audio/mp4, application/dicom. Application/dicom can contain the transfer syntax as a parameter.

Width can only be used for a photo or video

annotation.v2Mapping: RXO-1.2-Requested Give Code.text / RXE-2.2-Give Code.text / RXD-2.2-Dispense/Give Code.text / RXG-4.2-Give Code.text / RXA-5.2-Administered Code.text

annotation.definition: A code (or set of codes) that identify this medication. Usage note: This could be a standard drug code such as a drug regulator code, RxNorm code, SNOMED code, etc. It could also be a local formulary code, optionally with translations to the standard drug codes.
annotation.comment: When defining a medication, the code is the "identifying" code for the medication. All the codings provided should be at the same level in the hierarchy (generic, formulation, generic strength, etc.). Codes that relate the medication across the hierarchy should be conveyed using the relationships inherent in Medication.package and Medication.product.

annotations.shortDefinition: Administration of medication to a patient
annotations.definition:
Describes the event of a patient being given a dose of a medication. This may be as simple as swallowing a tablet or it may be a long running infusion.
Related resources tie this event to the authorizing prescription, and the specific encounter between patient and health care practitioner.
A nested type in MedicationAdministration: Indicates how the medication is to be used by the patient.

annotation.definition: The timing schedule for giving the medication to the patient. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
A coded specification of the anatomic site where the medication first enters the body.
A code specifying the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto a subject.

A coded value indicating the method by which the medication is introduced into or onto the body. Most commonly used for injections. Examples: Slow Push; Deep IV.
Terminologies used often pre-coordinate this term with the route and or form of administration.
The amount of themedication given at one administration event. Use this value when the administration is essentially an instantaneous event such as a swallowing a tablet or giving an injection.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXA-6-Administered Amount / RXA-7.1-Administered Units.code / RXA-7.3-Administered Units.name of coding system (uri<->code system mapping required)
annotation.todo: Expand notes on relationship between quantity and rate.

annotation.shortDefinition: Dose quantity per unit of time
annotation.definition: Identifies the speed with which the medication is introduced into the patient. Typically the rate for an infusion e.g. 200ml in 2 hours. May also expressed as a rate per unit of time such as 100ml per hour - the duration is then not specified, or is specified in the quantity.
annotation.todo: explain what happens if rate is not continuous.

annotation.shortDefinition: Total dose that should be consumed per unit of time
annotation.definition: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that my be administered to a subject over the period of time. E.g. 1000mg in 24 hours.

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationStatus
binding.definition: A set of codes indicating the current status of a MedicationAdministration

code.definition: The administration has started but has not yet completed.
Actions implied by the administration have been temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called "suspended".
All actions that are implied by the administration have occurred.
The administration was entered in error and therefore nullified.
Actions implied by the administration have been permanently halted, before all of them occurred.

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationNegationReason
binding.definition: A set of codes indicating the reason why the MedicationAdministration is negated.

annotation.definition: External identifier - FHIR will generate its own internal IDs (probably URLs) which do not need to be explicitly managed by the resource. The identifier here is one that would be used by another non-FHIR system - for example an automated medication pump would provide a record each time it operated; an administration while the patient was off the ward might be made with a different system and entered after the event. Particularly important if these records have to be updated.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXA-25-Administered Barcode Identifier? (V2 def'n of RXA-25 refers to the 'give' occurrence; appears not to discuss 'administer' cardinality which would seem to be 0..*)

annotation.shortDefinition: in progress | on hold | completed | entered in error | stopped
annotation.definition: Will generally be set to show that the administration has been completed. For some long running administrations such as infusions it is possible for an administration to be started but not completed or it may be paused while some other process is under way.
A link to a resource representing the person to whom the medication was given.
The individual who is responsible for giving the medication to the patient.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXA-10-Administering Provider / PRT-5-Participation Person: PRT-4-Participation='AP' (RXA-10 is deprecated)

annotation.definition: An link to a resource that identifies the particular occurrence of contact between patient and health care provider.
A link to a resource that provides the original request, instruction and authority to perform the administration.
annotation.v2Mapping: ORC-3-Filler Order Number / ORC-2-Placer Order Number

annotation.shortDefinition: True if asserting medication was not given
annotation.definition: Set this to true if the record is saying that the medication was NOT administered.

A code indicating why the administration has been negated.
Use only if isNegated is set to TRUE.
An interval of time during which the administration takes place. For many administrations, such as swallowing a tablet the lower and upper values of the interval will be the same.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXA-3-Date/Time Start of Administration / RXA-4-Date/Time End of Administration

annotation.definition: Identifies the medication being administered. This is either a link to a resource representing the details of the medication or a simple attribute carrying a code that identifies the medication from a known list of medications.
annotation.comment: Note: do not use Medication.name to describe the administered medication. When the only available information is a text description of the medication, Medication.code.text should be used.

annotation.definition: An identifier or a link to a resource that identifies a device used in administering the medication to the patient.

annotation.shortDefinition: Medicine administration instructions to the patient/carer
annotation.definition: Indicates how the medication is to be used by the patient.
annotation.todo: The RMIM has priority code on the act relationship. How do we handle this?.

annotations.shortDefinition: Dispensing a medication to a named patient
annotations.definition: Dispensing a medication to a named patient. This includes a description of the supply provided and the instructions for administering the medication.
A nested type in MedicationDispense: Indicates how the medication is to be used by the patient.

annotation.definition: Additional instructions such as "Swallow with plenty of water" which may or may not be coded.
annotation.rimMapping: RXE-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / RXO-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / TQ1-10-Condition Text / TQ1-11-Text Instruction ?

annotation.definition: The timing schedule for giving the medication to the patient. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
A coded specification of the anatomic site where the medication first enters the body.
A code specifying the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto a subject.

A coded value indicating the method by which the medication is introduced into or onto the body. Most commonly used for injections. Examples: Slow Push; Deep IV.
Terminologies used often pre-coordinate this term with the route and or form of administration.
The amount of the therapeutic or other substance given at one administration event.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-23-Give Rate Amount / RXE-24.1-Give Rate Units.code / RXE-24.3-Give Rate Units.name of coding system

annotation.shortDefinition: Dose quantity per unit of time
annotation.definition: Identifies the speed with which the substance is introduced into the subject. Typically the rate for an infusion. 200ml in 2 hours.

annotation.shortDefinition: Total dose that should be consumed per unit of time
annotation.definition: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that my be administered to a subject over the period of time. E.g. 1000mg in 24 hours.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MedicationDispense: Indicates whether or not substitution was made as part of the dispense. In some cases substitution will be expected but doesn't happen, in other cases substitution is not expected but does happen. This block explains what substitition did or did not happen and why.

annotation.definition: A code signifying whether a different drug was dispensed from what was prescribed.
annotation.committeeNotes: No substitution made or expected Subtitution made but not expected Substitution expected but not made Substitution made and expected.

annotation.definition: Indicates the reason for the substitution of (or lack of substitution) from what was prescribed.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who is responsible for the substitution
annotation.definition: The person or organization that has primary responsibility for the substitution.
annotation.committeeNotes: Who is this handled? Elsewhere attribution is handled by FHIR.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MedicationDispense: Indicates the details of the dispense event such as the days supply and quantity of medication dispensed.

annotation.definition: Identifier assigned by the dispensing facility. This is an identifier assigned outside FHIR.

annotation.shortDefinition: in progress | on hold | completed | entered in error | stopped
annotation.definition: A code specifying the state of the dispense event.
annotation.committeeNotes:
Active - processed but not pickup Completed - process and pickup Aborted - process and put back in stock
This is not related to partialFill whioch is really a partialFulfillment of the order.

annotation.definition: Indicates the type of dispensing event that is performed. Examples include: Trial Fill, Completion of Trial, Partial Fill, Emergency Fill, Samples, etc.
The amount of medication that has been dispensed. Includes unit of measure.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXD-4-Actual Dispense Amount / RXD-5.1-Actual Dispense Units.code / RXD-5.3-Actual Dispense Units.name of coding system

annotation.definition: Identifies the medication being administered. This is either a link to a resource representing the details of the medication or a simple attribute carrying a code that identifies the medication from a known list of medications.
annotation.comment: Note: do not use Medication.name to describe the dispensed medication. When the only available information is a text description of the medication, Medication.code.text should be used.

annotation.definition: The time the dispense event occurred.
annotation.committeeNotes: This is time of dispense (preparation). The time of supply to the patient is a separate attribute.

annotation.definition: The time the dispense event occurred.
annotation.committeeNotes: The time of supply to the patient (pickup/handover in community or supply in inpatient).

annotation.definition: Identification of the facility/location where the medication was shipped to, as part of the dispense event.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXD-13-Dispense-to Location; RXD-30-Dispense to Pharmacy; RXD-31-Dispense to Pharmacy Address (V2 (in definition of RXD-13, RXD-30 and RXD-31) directs use of the PRT segment but there doesn't appear to be a standard code in Table 0912 suitable for PRT-4-Participation)
annotation.committeeNotes:
for inpatient setting this is core, but this may not be core for community setting. Also core for internet pharmacy. Core for radioactive materials
Will service delivery location be defined by another group?.

annotation.definition: Identifies the person who picked up the medication.
annotation.committeeNotes: This is in the core because Controlled Drugs must be signed for and the recievers identiy must be recorded.

annotation.shortDefinition: Medicine administration instructions to the patient/carer
annotation.definition: Indicates how the medication is to be used by the patient.
annotation.committeeNotes: The RMIM has priority code on the act relationship. How do we handle this?.

binding.name: MedicationDispenseStatus
binding.description: Describes the lifecycle of the dispense.
binding.definition: A code specifying the state of the dispense event.

code.definition: The dispense has started but has not yet completed.
Actions implied by the administration have been temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called "suspended".
All actions that are implied by the dispense have occurred.
The dispense was entered in error and therefore nullified.
Actions implied by the dispense have been permanently halted, before all of them occurred.

binding.name: MedicationDispenseType
binding.definition: Indicates the type of dispensing event that is performed. Examples include: Trial Fill, Completion of Trial, Partial Fill, Emergency Fill, Samples, etc.

annotation.definition: Identifier assigned by the dispensing facility - this is an identifier assigned outside FHIR.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXA-25-Administered Barcode Identifier? (no unique dispense ID provided in RXD segment; V2 def'n of RXA-25 refers to the 'give' occurrence; appears not to discuss 'dispense' cardinality which would seem to be 0..*)

annotation.shortDefinition: in progress | on hold | completed | entered in error | stopped
annotation.definition: A code specifying the state of the set of dispense events.
annotation.v2Mapping: (Not clear whether or how V2 provides for a snapshot of dispense status)
annotation.committeeNotes:
Active - processed but not pickup Completed - process and pickup Aborted - process and put back in stock
This is not related to partialFill whioch is really a partialFulfillment of the order.

annotation.definition: A link to a resource representing the person to whom the medication will be given.
The individual reponsible for dispensing the medication.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXD-10-Dispensing Provider / PRT-5-Participation Person: PRT-4-Participation='DP' (RXD-10 is deprecated)

annotation.shortDefinition: Medication order that authorises the dispense
annotation.definition: Indicates the medication order that is being dispensed against.
annotation.v2Mapping: ORC-3-Filler Order Number / ORC-2-Placer Order Number

annotation.definition: Indicates the details of the dispense event such as the days supply and quantity of medication dispensed.
annotation.committeeNotes: How do we handle the sequence number when there are multiple instances of this event?.

annotation.shortDefinition: Deals with substitution of one medicine for another
annotation.definition: Indicates whether or not substitution was made as part of the dispense. In some cases substitution will be expected but doesn't happen, in other cases substitution is not expected but does happen. This block explains what substitition did or did not happen and why.

annotations.shortDefinition: Prescription of medication to for patient
annotations.definition: An order for both supply of the medication and the instructions for administration of the medicine to a patient.
A nested type in MedicationPrescription: Indicates how the medication is to be used by the patient.

annotation.definition: Free text dosage instructions for cases where the instructions are too complex to code.

annotation.definition: Additional instructions such as "Swallow with plenty of water" which may or may not be coded.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / RXO-7.2-Provider's Administration Instructions.text / TQ1-10-Condition Text / TQ1-11-Text Instruction ?

annotation.definition: The timing schedule for giving the medication to the patient. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
A coded specification of the anatomic site where the medication first enters the body.
A code specifying the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto a patient.

A coded value indicating the method by which the medication is introduced into or onto the body. Most commonly used for injections. Examples: Slow Push; Deep IV.
Terminologies used often pre-coordinate this term with the route and or form of administration.
The amount of the therapeutic or other substance given at one administration event.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-23-Give Rate Amount / RXE-24.1-Give Rate Units.code / RXE-24.3-Give Rate Units.name of coding system

annotation.shortDefinition: Dose quantity per unit of time
annotation.definition: Identifies the speed with which the substance is introduced into the subject. Typically the rate for an infusion. 200ml in 2 hours.

annotation.shortDefinition: Total dose that should be consumed per unit of time
annotation.definition: The maximum total quantity of a therapeutic substance that my be administered to a subject over the period of time. E.g. 1000mg in 24 hours.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MedicationPrescription: Indicates whether or not substitution can or should as part of the dispense. In some cases substitution must happen, in other cases substitution must not happen, and in others it does not matter. This block explains the prescribers intent. If nothing is specified substitution may be done.

annotation.definition: A code signifying whether a different drug should be dispensed from what was prescribed.
Indicates the reason for the substitution why substitution must or must not be performed.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MedicationPrescription: Deals with details of the dispense part of the order.

annotation.definition: Identifies the medication that is to be dispensed. This may be a more specifically defined than the medicationPrescription.medication . This is either a link to a resource representing the details of the medication or a simple attribute carrying a code that identifies the medication from a known list of medications.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-2-Give Code / RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

annotation.definition: Design Comments: This indicates the validity period of a prescription (stale dating the Prescription) It reflects the prescriber perspective for the validity of the prescription. Dispenses must not be made against the prescription outside of this period. The lower-bound of the Dispensing Window signifies the earliest date that the prescription can be filled for the first time. If an upper-bound is not specified then the Prescription is open-ended or will default to a stale-date based on regulations. Rationale: Indicates when the Prescription becomes valid, and when it ceases to be a dispensable Prescription.
An integer indicating the number of repeats of the Dispense. UsageNotes: For example, the number of times the prescribed quantity is to be supplied including the initial standard fill.
The amount that is to be dispensed.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXD-4-Actual Dispense Amount / RXD-5.1-Actual Dispense Units.code / RXD-5.3-Actual Dispense Units.name of coding system

annotation.definition: Identifies the period time over which the supplied product is expected to be used, or the length of time the dispense is expected to last. In some situations, this attribute may be used instead of quantity to identify the amount supplied by how long it is expected to last, rather than the physical quantity issued. E.g. 90 days supply of medication (based on an ordered dosage) When possible, it is always better to specify quantity, as this tends to be more precise. expectedSupplyDuration will always be an estimate that can be influenced by external factors.

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationMethod
binding.definition: A coded concept describing the technique by which the medicine is administered

binding.name: MedicationAdministrationSite
binding.definition: A coded concept describing the site location the medicine enters into or onto the body

binding.name: MedicationPrescriptionStatus
binding.definition: A code specifying the state of the prescribing event. Describes the lifecycle of the prescription.

code.definition: The prescription is 'actionable', but not all actions that are implied by it have occurred yet.
Actions implied by the prescription have been temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called "suspended".
All actions that are implied by the prescription have occurred (this will rarely be made explicit).
The prescription was entered in error and therefore nullified.
Actions implied by the prescription have been permanently halted, before all of them occurred.
The prescription was replaced by a newer one, which encompasses all the information in the previous one.

binding.name: MedicationIntendedSubstitutionType
binding.definition: A coded concept describing whether a different medicinal product may be dispensed other than the product as specified exactly in the prescription

binding.name: RouteOfAdministration
binding.definition: A coded concept describing the route or physiological path of administration of a therapeutic agent into or onto the body of a subject.

binding.name: MedicationPrescriptionReviewStatus
binding.definition: A coded concept describing the current status of any reviews planned or performed on the prescription

binding.name: MedicationIntendedSubstitutionReason
binding.definition: A coded concept describing the reason that a different medication should (or should not) be substituted from what was prescribed.

annotation.definition: External identifier - one that would be used by another non-FHIR system - for example a re-imbursement system might issue its own id for each prescription that is created. This is particularly important where FHIR only provides part of an erntire workflow process where records have to be tracked through an entire system.

annotation.definition: The date (and perhaps time) when the prescription was written.

A link to a resource representing the person to whom the medication will be given.
The healthcare professional responsible for authorising the prescription.

In some cases substitution must happen, in other cases substitution must not happen, and in others it does not matter. This block explains the prescribers intent. annotations.shortDefinition: A resource that describes a message that is exchanged between systems
annotations.definition: The header for a message exchange that is either requesting or responding to an action. The resource(s) that are the subject of the action as well as other Information related to the action are typically transmitted in a bundle of which the MessageHeader resource instance is the first resource in the bundle.
annotations.requirements: Many implementations are not prepared to use REST and need a messaging based infrastructure.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MessageHeader: The source application from which this message originated.

annotation.definition: Human-readable name for the target system.
annotation.requirements: May be used to support audit.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of software running the system
annotation.definition: May include configuration or other information useful in debugging.
annotation.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.

annotation.definition: Can convey versions of multiple systems in situations where a message passes through multiple hands.
annotation.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.
annotation.v2Mapping: SFT-2-software certified version or release number
annotation.committeeNotes: Version is not captured as a distinct property in v3.

annotation.definition: An e-mail, phone, website or other contact point to use to resolve issues with message communications.
annotation.requirements: Allows escalation of technical issues.
annotation.rimMapping: unique(./entity[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="DEV"]/scopesRole[normalRole() and classCode="CON" and layer[classCode="PSN"]/telecom[isNormalDatatype()])
annotation.committeeNotes: Should actually have a code for the role in the v3 mapping to indicate that the contact is for "problems".

annotation.shortDefinition: Actual message source address or id
annotation.definition: Identifies the routing target to send acknowledgements to.
annotation.comment: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
annotation.requirements: Identifies where to send responses, may influence security permissions.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MessageHeader: Information about the message that this message is a response to. Only present if this message is a response.

annotation.definition: The id of the message that this a response to.
annotation.requirements: Allows receiver to know what message is being responded to.

annotation.definition: Code that identifies the type of response to the message - whether it was successful or not, and whether it should be resent or not.
annotation.comment: This is a generic response to the request message. Specific data for the response will be found in MessageHeader.data.
annotation.requirements: Allows the sender of the acknowledge message to know if the request was successful or if action is needed.

annotation.definition: Full details of any issues found in the message.
annotation.comment: This SHALL be contained in the bundle. If any of the issues are errors, the response code SHALL be an error.
annotation.requirements: Allows the sender of the message to determine what the specific issues are.

annotations.definition: A nested type in MessageHeader: The destination application which the message is intended for.

annotation.definition: Human-readable name for the source system.
annotation.requirements: May be used for routing of response and/or to support audit.

annotation.shortDefinition: Particular delivery destination within the destination
annotation.definition: Identifies the target end system in situations where the initial message transmission is to an intermediary system.
annotation.requirements: Supports multi-hop routing.

annotation.definition: Indicates where the message should be routed to.
annotation.comment: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
annotation.requirements: Identifies where to route the message.
annotation.v2Mapping: MSH-25-receiving network address (or MSH-6-receiving facility by implication)

binding.name: ResponseType
binding.definition: The kind of response to a message

code.definition: The message was accepted and processed without error.

Some internal unexpected error occurred - wait and try again. Note - this is usually used for things like database unavailable, which may be expected to resolve, though human intervention may be required.
The message was rejected because of some content in it. There is no point in re-sending without change. The response narrative SHALL describe what the issue is.

binding.name: EventReason
binding.definition: Reason for event occurrence

annotation.definition: The identifier of this message.
annotation.comment: This SHALL be unique within the scope of this stream of messages.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time that the message was sent
annotation.definition: The time that the message was sent.
annotation.requirements: Allows limited detection of out-of-order and delayed transmission. Also supports audit.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code for the event this message represents
annotation.definition: Code that identifies the event this message represents and connects it with it's definition. Events defined as part of the FHIR specification have the system value "http://hl7.org/fhir/message-type".
annotation.requirements: Drives the behavior associated with this message.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this is a reply to prior message
annotation.definition: Information about the message that this message is a response to. Only present if this message is a response.
The source application from which this message originated.
annotation.requirements: Allows replies, supports audit.

annotation.definition: The destination application which the message is intended for.
annotation.comment: there SHOULD be at least one destination, but in some circumstances, the source system is unaware of any particular destination system.
annotation.requirements: Indicates where message is to be sent to for routing purposes. Allows verification of "am I the intended recipient".

annotation.shortDefinition: The source of the data entry
annotation.definition: The person or device that performed the data entry leading to this message. Where there is more than one candidate, pick the most proximal to the message. Can provide other enterers in extensions.
annotation.comment: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
annotation.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

annotations.shortDefinition: Simple observations
annotations.definition: Simple assertions and measurements made about a patient, device or other subject.
annotations.comment: Used for simple observations such as device measurements, laboratory atomic results, vital signs, height, weight, smoking status, comments, etc. Other resources are used to describe aggregate collections of observations such as Lab reports, etc.
annotations.requirements: Observations are a key aspect of healthcare. This resource is used to capture those that do not require more sophisticated mechanisms.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Observation: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.

annotation.definition: The value of the low bound of the reference range. If this is omitted, the low bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. E.g. <2.3.
annotation.comment: Do not use the comparator for < or >.

annotation.definition: The value of the high bound of the reference range. If this is omitted, the high bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. E.g. >5.
annotation.comment: Do not use the comparator for < or >.

annotation.definition: Code for the meaning of the reference range.
annotation.comment: This is SHOULD be populated if there is more than one range.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to say what kind of reference range this is - normal, recommended, therapeutic, or perhaps what state this reference range applies to (i.e. age, hormonal cycles, etc.).

annotation.definition: The age at which this reference range is applicable. This is a neonatal age (e.g. number of weeks at term) if the meaning says so.
annotation.requirements: Some analytes vary greatly over age.

binding.name: ObservationMethod
binding.definition: Methods for simple observations

binding.name: ObservationType
binding.description: LOINC codes filtered to exclude panel codes
binding.definition: Codes identifying types of simple observations

binding.name: ObservationRangeMeaning
binding.definition: Code for the meaning of a reference range

binding.name: ObservationReliability
binding.definition: Codes that provide an estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value of an observation

code.definition: The result has no reliability concerns.
An early estimate of value; measurement is still occurring.
An early estimate of value; processing is still occurring.
The observation value should be treated with care.
The result has been generated while calibration is occurring.
The observation could not be completed because of an error.
No observation value was available.

binding.name: ObservationStatus
binding.definition: Codes providing the status of an observation

code.definition: The existence of the observation is registered, but there is no result yet available.
This is an initial or interim observation: data may be incomplete or unverified.
The observation is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The observation has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The observation is unavailable because the measurement was not started or not completed (also sometimes called "aborted").
The observation has been withdrawn following previous Final release.

binding.name: ObservationInterpretation
binding.definition: Codes identifying interpretations of observations

annotation.definition: Describes what was observed. Sometimes called this is called the observation "code".
annotation.requirements: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.

annotation.definition: The information determined as a result of making the observation.
annotation.comment: The datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.name. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.name. The element, Observation.value[x], has a variable name depending on the type as follows: valueQuantity, valueCodeableConcept, valueRatio, valueChoice, valuePeriod, valueSampleData, or valueString (The name format is "'value' + the type name" with a capital on the first letter of the type).
annotation.requirements: A result with no value isn't much use. (Though an exceptional value such as 'unknown' may still be useful.).

annotation.definition: The assessment made based on the result of the observation.
annotation.requirements: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.

annotation.definition: May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to provide free text additional information.
annotation.v2Mapping: NTE.3 (partner NTE to OBX, or sometimes another (child?) OBX)

annotation.definition: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time".
annotation.comment: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report.
annotation.requirements: Knowing when an observation was deemed true is important to its relevance as well as determining trends.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBX-14-date/time of the observation, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4 (depends on who observation made)

annotation.definition: Date/Time this was made available.
annotation.comment: Updated when the result is updated.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

annotation.definition: The status of the result value.
annotation.requirements: Need to track the status of individual results - some results are finalised before the whole report is finalised.
annotation.rimMapping:
status
Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

annotation.shortDefinition: ok | ongoing | early | questionable | calibrating | error +
annotation.definition: An estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value reported.
annotation.comment: Note that in most contexts, unreliable results are not recorded, deleted, or otherwise excluded, but it's not always possible to exclude them from the record. Interpreters of a result, whether human or machine, SHALL always either be aware of the status, or prevented from using the observation without being unaware that the reliability is not "ok".
annotation.requirements: Not all results are completely reliable, and some are still reported anyway.

annotation.definition: Indicates where on the subject's body the observation was made.
annotation.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.name.
annotation.requirements: Knowing where the observation is made is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.
annotation.committeeNotes: Is this in the 80%?.

annotation.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
annotation.comment: Only used if not implicit in code for Observation.name.
annotation.requirements: In some cases, method can impact results and is thus for determining whether results can be compared or determining significance of results.
annotation.committeeNotes: Is this in the 80%?.

annotation.shortDefinition: Unique Id for this particular observation
annotation.definition: A unique identifier for the simple observation.
annotation.requirements: Allows observations to be distinguished and referenced.

annotation.definition: The thing the observation is being made about.
annotation.comment: The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.
annotation.requirements: Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about.

annotation.definition: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
annotation.comment: Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but usually by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources are often used in contexts that track the specimen explicity (e.g. Diagnostic Report).

annotation.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
annotation.comment: This would only be "Device" if the device is responsible for the measurement, not to capture the device used by a human to make the measurement. (The latter could be captured as an extension.).
annotation.requirements: May give a degree of confidence in the observation and also indicates where follow-up questions should be directed.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBX.15 / (Practitioner) OBX-16-responsible observer, PRT-5-participation person:PRT-4-participation='RO' / (Device) OBX-18-equipment instance identifier , PRT-10-participation device:PRT-4-participation='EQUIP' / (Organization) OBX-23-performing organization name, PRT-8-participation organization:PRT-4-participation='PO'

annotation.definition: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
annotation.comment: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g. specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this may not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.
annotation.requirements: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

invariant.human: Can only have normal range if value is a quantity

annotations.shortDefinition: Information about the success/failure of an action
annotations.definition: A collection of error, warning or information messages that result from a system action.
annotations.comment: Can result from the failure of a REST call or be part of the response message returned from a request message. If sent with extensions overriding particular issues, might even appear as part of a request message.

annotations.definition: A nested type in OperationOutcome: An error, warning or information message that results from a system action.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the issue indicates a variation from successful processing.

annotation.requirements: Indicates how relevant the issue is to the overall success of the action.

annotation.definition: A code indicating the type of error, warning or information message.
annotation.comment: Codes should only be defined at a level of granularity that reasonably allows distinct actions to be taken by the receiving system. If the response behavior of all systems is the same for two codes, the codes might as well be merged. The human-meaningful content of the issue is conveyed in .text.
annotation.requirements: Expresses the issue in a computer-friendly way, allowing the requesting system to behave differently based on the type of issue.

annotation.definition: Additional description of the issue.
annotation.comment: typically this field is used to provide details human-readable information about the error.

annotation.shortDefinition: XPath of element(s) related to issue
annotation.definition: A simple XPath limited to element names, repetition indicators and the default child access that identifies one of the elements in the resource that caused this issue to be raised.
annotation.comment: The root of the XPath is the resource or bundle that generated OperationOutcome. Each XPath SHALL resolve to a single node. The XPath syntax is used whether the referenced instance is expressed in XML or JSON.
annotation.requirements: Allows systems to highlight or otherwise guide users to elements implicated in issues to allow them to be fixed more easily.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that is associated with the contact
annotation.definition: Organization on behalf of which the contact is acting or for which the contact is working.
annotation.requirements: For guardians or business related contacts, the organization is relevant.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: This element has a value if the patient is an animal.

annotation.definition: Identifies the high level categorization of the kind of animal.
annotation.comment: If the patient is non-human, at least a species SHALL be specified.
annotation.requirements: Need to know what kind of animal.

annotation.definition: Identifies the detailed categorization of the kind of animal.
annotation.requirements: May need to know the specific kind within the species.

annotation.definition: Indicates the current state of the animal's reproductive organs.
annotation.requirements: Gender status can affect housing and animal behavior.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person.

annotation.shortDefinition: The other patient resource that the link refers to
annotation.definition: The other patient resource that the link refers to.

annotation.shortDefinition: replace | refer | seealso - type of link
annotation.definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

binding.name: AnimalGenderStatus
binding.definition: The state of the animal's reproductive organs

binding.name: LinkType
binding.definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

code.definition: The patient resource containing this link must no longer be used. The link points forward to another patient resource that must be used in lieu of the patient resource that contains the link.

The patient resource containing this link is in use and valid but not considered the main source of information about a patient. The link points forward to another patient resource that should be consulted to retrieve additional patient information.

The patient resource containing this link is in use and valid, but points to another patient resource that is known to contain data about the same person. Data in this resource might overlap or contradict information found in the other patient resource. This link does not indicate any relative importance of the resources concerned, and both should be regarded as equally valid.

binding.name: AnimalBreed
binding.definition: The breed of an animal

binding.name: AnimalSpecies
binding.definition: The species of an animal

binding.name: ContactRelationship
binding.definition: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient

annotation.shortDefinition: An identifier for the person as this patient
annotation.definition: An identifier that applies to this person as a patient.
annotation.requirements: Patients are almost always assigned specific numerical identifiers.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the patient
annotation.definition: A name associated with the individual.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods.For animals, the name is a "HumanName" in the sense that is assigned and used by humans and has the same patterns.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the person by multiple names. Examples are your official name and a partner name.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the individual
annotation.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the individual may be contacted.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently and also to help with identification. The address may not go directly to the individual, but may reach another party that is able to proxy for the patient (i.e. home phone, or pet owner's phone).
annotation.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the patient is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
annotation.comment: The gender may not match the biological sex as determined by genetics, or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than M and F, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support M and F.
annotation.requirements: Needed for identification of the individual, in combination with (at least) name and birth date. Gender of individual drives many clinical processes.
annotation.committeeNotes: 'gender' is still the administrative gender, but this is reflected in its description rather than its name.

annotation.shortDefinition: The date and time of birth for the individual
annotation.definition: The date and time of birth for the individual.
annotation.comment: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real dob is unknown.
annotation.requirements: Age of the individual drives many clinical processes. Next to the common use case of capturing someone birth date, also in some common cases time is registered.
annotation.committeeNotes: renamed from dob, because the abbreviation is not obvious to non-English speakers.

annotation.shortDefinition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not
annotation.definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
annotation.comment: If there's no value in the instance it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.
annotation.requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.
annotation.rimMapping: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd, player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

annotation.definition: Addresses for the individual.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods.
annotation.requirements: May need to keep track of persons addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements and also to help with identification.

annotation.definition: This field contains a patient's most recent marital (civil) status.
annotation.requirements: Most, if not all systems capture it.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether patient is part of a multiple birth
annotation.definition: Indicates whether the patient is part of a multiple or indicates the actual birth order.
annotation.requirements: For disambiguation of multiple-birth children, especially relevant where the care provider doesn't meet the patient, such as labs.

annotation.definition: Image of the person.
annotation.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of the patient. Fits with newer social media usage too.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient
annotation.definition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient.
annotation.comment: Contact covers all kinds of contact parties: family members, business contacts, guardians, caregivers. Not applicable to register pedigree and family ties beyond use of having contact.
annotation.requirements: Need to track people you can contact about the patient.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this patient is an animal (non-human)
annotation.definition: This element has a value if the patient is an animal.
annotation.comment: The animal element is labeled "Is Modifier" since patients may be non-human. Systems SHALL either handle patient details appropriately (e.g. inform users patient is not human) or reject non-human patient records.
annotation.requirements: Many clinical systems are extended to care for animal patients as well as human.

annotation.shortDefinition: Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
annotation.definition: Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health.
annotation.comment: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken. For animals, language is not a relevant field, and should be absent from the instance.
annotation.requirements: If a patient does not speak the local language, interpreters may be required, so languages spoken is an important things to keep track of both for patient and other persons of interest.
annotation.committeeNotes: Define proficiency and mode as extensions.

annotation.definition: Patient's nominated care provider.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record
annotation.definition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record.
annotation.requirements: Need to know who recognises this patient record, manages and updates it.

annotation.shortDefinition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person
annotation.definition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person.
annotation.comment: There is no assumption that linked patient records have mutual links.
annotation.requirements: There are multiple usecases: * Duplicate patient records due to the clerical errors associated with the difficulties of identifying humans consistently, and * Distribution of patient information across multiple servers.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether this patient's record is in active use
annotation.definition: Whether this patient record is in active use.
annotation.comment: Default is true. If a record is inactive, and linked to an active record, then future patient/person/record updates should occur on the other patient.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to mark a patient record as not to be used because it was created in error.

search.name: animal-breed
search.description: The breed for animal patients

search.name: phonetic
search.description: A portion of either family or given name using some kind of phonetic matching algorithm

search.name: link
search.description: All patients linked to the given patient

search.name: provider
search.description: The organization at which this person is a patient

search.name: animal-species
search.description: The species for animal patients

search.name: _id
search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.name: given
search.description: A portion of the given name of the patient

search.name: address
search.description: An address in any kind of address/part of the patient

search.name: family
search.description: A portion of the family name of the patient

search.name: name
search.description: A portion of either family or given name of the patient

search.name: telecom
search.description: The value in any kind of telecom details of the patient

search.name: birthdate
search.description: The patient's date of birth

search.name: gender
search.description: Gender of the patient

search.name: active
search.description: Whether the patient record is active

search.name: language
search.description: Language code (irrespective of use value)

search.name: identifier
search.description: A patient identifier

annotations.shortDefinition: A person with a formal responsibility in the provisioning of healthcare or related services
annotations.definition: Demographics and qualification information for an individual who is directly or indirectly involved in the provisioning of healthcare.
annotations.comment: Note that a cab driver no longer fits the bill. You probably would be interested in the organization rather than the individual?.
annotations.requirements: Need to track doctors, staff, locums etc. for both healthcare practitioners, funders, etc.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Practitioner: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

annotation.definition: Coded representation of the qualification.

annotation.shortDefinition: Period during which the qualification is valid
annotation.definition: Period during which the qualification is valid.
annotation.requirements: Qualifications are often for a limited period of time, and can be revoked.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification
annotation.definition: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification.

binding.name: Qualification
binding.definition: Specific qualification the practitioner has to provide a service

binding.name: PractitionerSpecialty
binding.definition: Specific specialty associated with the agency

binding.name: PractitionerRole
binding.definition: The role a person plays representing an organization

annotation.shortDefinition: A identifier for the person as this agent
annotation.definition: An identifier that applies to this person in this role.
annotation.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the agent.
annotation.committeeNotes: Under "Comments" it said: "The identifier changes when a new/different person steps into the same role". This depends on business rules, I would assume a new instance is created instead. did keep the text here just in case.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the person
annotation.definition: A name associated with the person.
annotation.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that person.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the practitioner
annotation.definition: A contact detail for the practitioner, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
annotation.requirements: Need to know how to reach a practitioner.

annotation.shortDefinition: One or more addresses for the practitioner
annotation.definition: One or more addresses where the practitioner can be found or visited.
annotation.requirements: Need to keep track where the practitioner can found during work or for directing mail.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
annotation.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

annotation.shortDefinition: The date and time of birth for the practitioner
annotation.definition: The date and time of birth for the practitioner.
annotation.requirements: Needed for identification.

annotation.definition: Image of the person.
annotation.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of patients and personnel. Fits with newer social media usage too.

annotation.definition: The organization that the practitioner represents.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the represented organization separately, if any.
annotation.v2Mapping: PRD-10 (-> 14) / PRA-9-Institution / PRT-8-Participation Organization for person participation

annotation.shortDefinition: Roles which this practitioner may perform
annotation.definition: Roles which this practitioner is authorized perform for the organization.
annotation.comment: A person may have more than one role. At least one role is required.
annotation.requirements: Need to know what authority the practitioner has - what can they do?.
annotation.v2Mapping: PRD-1 / STF-18-job title / PRA-3-practitioner category / PRT-4-Participation / ROL-3-role-ROL / ORC-12-ordering provider / OBR-16-ordering provider / PV1-7-attending doctor / PV1-8-referring doctor / PV1-9-consulting doctor / PV1-17-admitting doctor

annotation.definition: Specific specialty of the practitioner.

annotation.shortDefinition: The period during which the practitioner is authorized to perform in these role(s)
annotation.definition: The period during which the person is authorized to act as a practitioner in these role(s) for the organization.
annotation.requirements: Even after the agencies is revoked, the fact that it existed must still be recorded.
annotation.committeeNotes: Is this separate from the period of validity of the qualification?.

annotation.shortDefinition: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care
annotation.definition: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.

annotation.shortDefinition: Qualifications obtained by training and certification
annotation.definition: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

annotation.shortDefinition: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication
annotation.definition: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication.
annotation.comment: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
annotation.requirements: Knowing which language a practitioner speaks can help in facilitating communication with patients.
annotation.committeeNotes: Note: cannot be named "language" because of technical reasons.

search.name: organization
search.description: The identity of the organization the practitioner represents / acts on behalf of

search.description: A portion of the given name
